While the lack of revenue and the inability to attract international talent are significant challenges, there are several other challenges that Liga I clubs may be facing due to the pandemic. 

One significant challenge is the mental and physical health of players. The prolonged suspension of matches and training, as well as the constant uncertainty surrounding fixtures, can take a toll on the mental and physical health of the players. Clubs need to pay attention to their players' well-being and provide mental health support during this challenging time to maintain high levels of performance.

Another challenge is the limited opportunities for players to be seen by scouts or potential buyers, which affects their market value. With tournaments and matches being cancelled or postponed, players have limited opportunities to showcase their talents on a global stage, making it tough for Liga I players to attract interest from top clubs or scouts.

The pandemic has also affected the infrastructure and quality of training facilities available to clubs. With the implementation of social distancing measures, clubs may face challenges with proper training venues and equipment, which impacts the quality of the training sessions.

Finally, the pandemic has created challenges with sponsorships and marketing partnerships. Many organizations cut budgets due to the pandemic, which may force Liga I clubs to seek alternative sources of revenue and partnerships. 

Ultimately, Liga I clubs have to balance the challenges created by the pandemic, and innovative solutions may be necessary to overcome them.
